reviewText: Choplifter HD is only recommendable to people who don't mind a severe old school" challenge. Everyone else will probably find the game too frustrating
date: even on the lower difficultly levels.\n\nLike the 1980s original
recommended: Choplifter HD puts you in control of a helicopter and tasks you with rescuing people and bringing them back to safety. Enemies dot the levels and they'll take shots at you; if your helicopter takes too many hits you'll blow up. Likewise
hoursPlayed: if you run out of fuel
voteText: you'll crash. Choplifter HD becomes a game of risk management; do you have enough fuel to make it to the next person who needs to be rescued
helpfulPercent: or should you turn back to refuel and repair first? The clock is ticking...\n\nAll of this is fine
votesHelpful: and is keeping in the spirit of the original game. Where Choplifter HD veers off-course is in the difficulty: this game is tough as nails. The first two or three levels are easy enough
votesTotal: but the difficulty spikes severely from that point on. Levels are jam-packed with enemies that can take your health down in a flash and many of them re-spawn after a short time
votesFunny: meaning you have to deal with them over and over. Enemies with RPGs and EMP rifles that stand on rooftops are very hard to spot
commentsCount: and later on you'll have to avoid missiles fired from jets as well as incoming mortar fire. There are even tanks and AA cannons that can take you out in a couple of hits. It's almost impossible to avoid taking damage in Choplifter HD
column16: so get used to restarting some levels multiple times before you finally conquer them.\n\nIf the campaign becomes too much to take
column17: Choplifter HD also has a zombie mode: here
column18: you fly back and forth across a besieged city
column19: shooting zombies and rescuing people. It's fun for a while.\n\nOne other thing worth mentioning: the awful voice-acting. Throughout Choplifter HD
column20: you'll be treated to poorly-written and voiced jokes and one-liners from your chopper's crew. None of the jokes are funny
column21: and they're repeated over and over. Some of the dialog is surprisingly tasteless too. Turn your speakers off.\n\nIf you're one of those people who think that modern games have become too "casual"
column22: then Choplifter HD is for you."

reviewText:
Having played the original in the late 80's as a kid in amusement arcades, it was hard to resist purchasing this very addictive game.  It's worth purchasing the Night Avenger dlc helicopter as some missions are quite difficult to get a perfect 5 stars.  The more stars you acquire the better helicopter upgrade you receive, you have to use non dlc helicopters to complete a mission before being able to use any powerful dlc helicopters you may have purchased.

Zombie! Zombie! Zombie! dlc level pack is worth buying also but not necessary to complete the game.

You can easily play this game off onboard Intel HD Graphics 3000 very well, the graphics are superb.

Bought in the Christmas 2013 steam sale with 75% off.

reviewText:
Choplifter HD is a spiritual successor of the original Choplift on Apple II. The mechanics are simiar, but updated. The chopper is in 2D space: it can go left, right, up and down. It can turn left, right, or face the player (out), and this is important as enemies do come from 3 directions (left, right, and out). And you can't hit the enemy if you're facing the wrong way. The game is presented in 3D with parallax and real scrolling to give the impression of 3D but the actual movesments are 2D.

Different helicopters have different handling, such as firepower, speed, carrying capacity, fuel capacity, and so on. Armed helis have missiles and/or chain gun, and all helis need to rescue people (civilians or soldiers or even the occasional news crew).  As you play you will unlock better helos by achieving stars" on the missions.

Enemies have AAA gun sites
voteText: technical (gun trucks)
commentsCount: and just general terrain obstructions.\n\nYour objective is basically to rescue as many people that needs to be rescued as possible by flying there
column17: land next to the people (not ON them!) so they get on
column18: then fly back to your base
column20: and repeat until either time runs out
column21: or you rescued them all and/or other missions. It can get frantic
column22: when you have enemies on all sides
column24: and so on.\n\nIn many ways this is a twin joystick shooter
column25: as the left stick controls the chopper while the right stick controls the aim (laser sight pointing the chain gun).\n\nFuel is limited
column26: and any use of "turbo" (speed boost) eats up fuel like crazy. And your helo won't fly without fuel. Rockets are limited in qty and reloaded only at base. Chaingun is infinite but there's a heat limit to prevent it from firing too much. Carrying capacity is limited  and the larger choppers don't fly as fast or move as nimbly as the smaller ones. On the other hand
column27: they can often do everything in one trip rather than taking multiple trips.\n\nThere are various "campaigns" containing various missions
column28:
and each mission usually has a bonus objective as well as news crew to rescue (2 extra people!)

DLC packs adds extra helos to play with (some are very powerful) and more missions.

All in all

reviewText: Do you remember when we used to play choplifter on Atari or VIC 20 or Nintendo? This is the same game but the leap of graphics and side missions and weapons can't help to make this almost a completely different game. Most importantly is it's sill fun to play. There's fun to be had here but an hour into the game it gets repetative. This game forces you to be conservative and yet rushing at the same time. That fuel gauge drives me nuts half the time because I hate leaving any enemy placements without blowing them up, but if you try... you are gonna run outta gas. It's a madding balancing act of destroying enough to get to the men you need to rescue and still getting your chopper out in one piece. Half the time you feel like you are juggling too much as you deal with enemies on the ground and foreground while running on fumes and you chopper is taking damage as you wait for men to board. This is one of the first games I recommend but not as much as I would like. The funs here but this game will overwhelm and tick you off at times too.

reviewText: Choplift is rooted HEAVILY in the shoes of the original game which I played back in the Commodore 64 days, and for that nostalgia value alone I had a blast playing.  This update adds some new variety of missions and a boatload of graphical and narratives additions, but the core game is rooted to the concept that made Choplifter an enduring favorite all those years ago... though whether you enjoy this may depend heavily on whether you actually are old enough to have cut your teeth on these types of games.  If you are this is definitely worth $10, and if not it's easily worth $5 to try it for awhile.\n\nMy 2 complaints: Some of the mid to late missions need knife-edged precision to beat which can be frustrating old-school style, and it's made worse by the fact that the DLC choppers (which effectively enable a God-mode ability) can only be used once you beat the mission in standard mode.  Secondly the narrative humor is usually groan-worthy at best and HORRIBLY IRRITATING at worst.

reviewText:
Have you ever played on a Commodore 64? Sitting there playing a game like Choplifter with a stick, staring into a tube television trying to safe all the poor people trapped in crossfire, while bombing tanks and shooting military plains.
If you have ever played Choplifter like that, don't even think, just buy. To anyone who have not had the pleasure to game like that, I'm sorry! But don't hold back because of that. It's still a really fun game, and you find yourself starting over in agony, that one guy died because you didn't do it good enough.

Why are you still reading? Go game this instead!
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I was never a huge fan of the arcade Choplifter or even Choplifter 2 on the Gameboy. I did take a liking to Choplifter 3 on the Super Nintendo because of the huge advancements in gameplay that it offered. My liking to Choplifter 3 wavered alot after discovering the game's crippling difficulty after reaching just the first boss in the first world. Still I like the game and plan to tough it out through the game someday. But someday is gonna have to wait even longer now because here comes CHOPLIFTER HD!

Choplifter HD plays absolutely perfect. The visuals are very budget Direct X9 but a game does not need shiny visuals to achieve greatness. The developers added in much more than I would have ever thought of. One of the things that gets me everytime is the hilarious and not to mention timely pilot and co-pilot dialog while playing. The voice work is extremely well done. The controls perfectly compliment the stellar action in this game. I highly recommend a XBOX 360 controller or Logitech dual shock because they are set up perfectly to compitently control your helecopter and it's weapons. The new laser sight aiming system is very accurate and fun to use.

Choplifter HD is a model game for any remake of a retro title. The star rating system for level of completion makes you want to go back and try again until you achieve a 5 star rating. You unlock better helecopters as you gain more stars. There is also a hard mode which is unlocked after you beat the game on normal. This game is cheap and seriously fun.

reviewText:
Choplifter is a sidescrolling arcade game, in which you pilot a rescue helicopter which must save civillians in warzones while fending off enemy troops. Choplifter was an old favorite of mine when I grew up; I played it often on the Commodore. When I saw the remake, I just had to get it.

The game both succeeds and fails in a number of ways. It does a good job of replicating the gameplay of the original, and while they've added some more features, including multiple weapons, a speed boost, limited fuel and different chopper types, it's similar enough that the game feels very nostalgic.

There's also more enemy types, including AA guns and RPGs, and the various stages show off mediocre, but visually pleasing environments from cities to deserts and jungles. Furthermore, there's some mildly humorous comments from your co-pilot and the various people you pick up during the game.

Unfortunately, you have to deal with aiming controls which often don't work properly (you can aim in an arc around your chopper, and if often doesn't recognize your mouse unless you're in a sweet spot), and AI which often spoils your fun. It's not uncommon to fly in to rescue a civilian who then promptly runs in under your chopper and kills himself, or takes forever to figure out how to board the helicopter. These issues aren't severe enough that you'll hate the game, but you will be annoyed by it occasionally.


CONCLUSION:
If you're a fan of the original, it's worth taking a look. Even if this is your first encounter with it, it has the appeal of an addicting flash game - kind of entertaining, but very difficult to put down once you start playing. It probably doesn't have too much lasting appeal and it's still kind of broken, but if you wanna kill time, it does the job.

This comes as a HUGE dissappointment considering this is from the same company that made The Bard's Tale. The attempt at humor fails almost completely and also introduces an annoying reporter, Scoop Sanderson" (LOL SEE WAT THEY DID THUR?). Thankfully you can mute ALL the voices completely.\n\nThat being said

reviewText: The original Choplifter was a revolutionary Apple II/e game that featured a pixel helicopter navigating a post-apocalyptic world covered in Sno Balls, rescuing the survivors from diabetes or something. The remake is mechanically sound and challenging, but it settles into a rut after an hour or so. But there's Duke Nukem in this game!!! If you find him maybe he'll say something that is vaguely interpreted as badass! Like, I ♥♥♥♥ed your mother with this helicopter" or "Can you loan me twenty bucks for the sex machine????""

reviewText: This is a great and entertaining game with graphics that were better then I expected. However playing this game did not properly prepare me to fly a helicopter. So when I was in this helicopter the pilot had a stroke and i thought I could take over because of my time playing this game. Boy was that a mistake. long story short helicopter crashed and I blame this game for not teaching me to fly one properly

reviewText: A fun game that remindes me of SNES game with the excate same name. I higly recommend using a xbox controller because its simpler to controll the machine turret gun with it rather using the mouse and keyboard. Simple but entertaining. Kill enemy soldiers, rescue hostages, refuel on to the next mission (probably bosses later in the game). If they had steam trading cards id give it a full thumbs up.

reviewText: To start, I bought this at Office Max for $4, thinking it was a joke. When I installed it, I discovered a really fun, really challenging game! It is a remake of the classic game Choplifter, using the Unreal engine. It has lots of Helecopters to unlock, and is all-around fun and comical. The graphics are actually pretty good, and it has that classic pc game challenge. Great game!

reviewText: This is a fun game but the only complaint I have are jets.... The jets will make you stop playing the game because you have a limited reaction time to them. Otherwise this is a fun game that reminds me of some of the older games.\n\nEDIT: one other complaint I have is the Zombie dlc, I cannot tell you how fustrating it is to play through an entire mission only to get to the end of the mission and to have it crash. It doesn't happen all of the time so I was able to get through the campaign but it happened a lot and man was it annoying.

reviewText:
Play this IF you LOVE Old School 2-D side scrolling shooters OR if you played almost ANY version of Choplifter and enjoyed it. This game is for you. It is rather short and can be mastered fairly quickly, although the difficulty option can extend that.

This is very much like the old school Choplifter with a new coat of paint and FX visuals. But this is a great game because of those features. The price is just about right with the extra DLC being a worthwhile investment and help extend play time trying out all the chopper types.

The sounds are great, with a ton of funny banter between the pilots. The zombie missions are actually fun and you will find yourself backtracking so watch out for spawning enemies. Overall I really loved this game. I've enjoyed all of the STRIKE series (Sega genesis, Sega Saturn, PS1) and this makes a welcome addition if you enjopyed playing those games or older variations of Choplifter. This is a sound gaming investment for me as even 4 years later I still find time to fire it up occasionally to play.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: If you are new to choplifter, you may get a kick out of it for a while but if you've played choplifter going back to Apple IIe, then you are probably who I'm speaking to most in this review. As good as this is with modern graphics and sound, nothing beats the original on a green/black screen with blips for sound... Thats just mho. Can't recreate a classic but this is a fun game lacking the original charm.
